## Part 2: Antibiotic Resistance  

Staph infections can range from minor skin problems to life-threatening infections of the heart. They are caused by *Staphylococcus* bacteria, which is commonly found on the skin or in the nose of healthy individuals. Treatment typically depends on antibiotics, however some staph infections no longer respond to common antibiotics (are resistant to them, instead of susceptible to being killed by them).

Researchers are interested in knowing how resistant *Staphylococcus* bacteria are to the antibiotic Erythromycin. The researchers work at a lab that maintains a variety of *Staphylococcus* cultures for research purposes. They randomly selected 20 isolated *Staphylococcus* cultures from the lab's collection and ran Kirby-Bauer tests on each to determine their antibiotic resistance to Erythromycin. A uniform circular zone of no bacterial growth around the antibiotic disk is known as the Zone of Inhibition (ZOI) and is measured in millimeters (mm). If the bacteria is susceptible to the antibiotic, then no bacteria will grow close to the disk because it will be killed by the medication. Specifically, ZOI of less than 14mm would be considered resistant while 14mm-22mm is considered moderate resistance and anything larger is susceptible.
